awd_titl_txt: Ubiquitous Doubling Algorithms for Nonlinear Matrix Equations and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal investigator's (PI's) research is aimed at the solution of practical problems of optimal control theory from areas as diverse as vibration analysis for high speed trains and quantum transport in nano research. Underlying these applications are formulations that require the efficient and accurate solution of important nonlinear matrix equations which critically influence the overall performance and fidelity of the entire simulations. Past experience has shown that practically relevant simulations requiring solutions of nonlinear matrix equations are notoriously challenging to the point that computed solutions may be completely erroneous. This project aims at changing the status quo by developing a complete theory, devising innovative algorithms to better reflect problem structures, and designing more robust implementations. In addition to advancing research in these nonlinear matrix equations, the PI will recruit and train graduate students in computational mathematics and interdisciplinary studies.

This project will advance the understanding and solution techniques for high impact nonlinear matrix equations in the context of mathematical theory, computational methods, and software. For decades, computational scientists and engineers have been struggling to compute trustworthy numerical solutions to some of these nonlinear matrix equations with limited success. For example, the entries of the solution matrices to M-matrix algebraic Riccati equations from Markov-modulated fluid flow theory represent probabilities of events, and tiny entries indicate events that are rare but still important,  and thus need to be computed accurately. The eigenvalues from vibration analysis of high speed trains vary widely in magnitude beyond the ranges that the IEEE double precision can handle if not dealt with correctly. The doubling algorithm may not converge at all on the unperturbed nonlinear matrix equations for quantum transport in nano research. These difficulties are often not caused by the large sizes of the problems but rather are more due to their inherent mathematical properties. With the successful completion of this project, a complete and coherent unifying framework of doubling algorithms, along with the relevant theory, will be developed. A much deeper understanding of doubling algorithms will be gained, and it is possible that important applications will be identified where doubling algorithms can be utilized and are faster than the current state-of-the-art methods. More significantly, the theory developed will assure that the new algorithms will produce more trustworthy accurate numerical results than is currently possible.

por.por_cntn:
Often numerical computations proceed iteratively from one approximation to the next, yielding a sequence of increasingly accurate ones towards its target. The doubling algorithm is an ability of skipping many but computing only just few such approximations. It is a beautiful idea but not always possible. However when it works, the algorithm is very fast and often produces more trustworthy approximations than existing methods,too.

This project focuses on on nonlinear matrix equations of practical significance, most notably with impactful applications in the optimal control theory, the applied probability and transportation theory and Markov-modulated fluid queue theory, quantum transport in nano research, and vibration analysis of fast trains, for example. Major outcomes of the project are as follows. Firstly, we established a unified framework and theory of doubling algorithms that make the doubling technique "transparent" to new comers. Secondly, we developed the doubling algorithm for the most fundamental quadratic matrix equations from the quasi-birth-and-death process (QBD) with high relative entrywise accuracy. Thirdly, we solved two practical problems from the Markov-modulated fluid queue theory: the shifted M-matrix algebraic Riccati equation and a type of structured M-matrix algebraic Riccati equation. Fourthly, we expanded our efforts to other types of nonlinear matrix equations during the course of the project, namely, Nonlinear Eigenvalue Problems with Eigenvector-Dependency(NEPv). They appear frequently these days in many data science applications as the first order optimality condition, also known as the KKT conditions of certain optimization problems on the Stiefel manifolds. Customized iterations have been designed and well demonstrated to show their high effectiveness in significantly lifting learning performance.

We combined our research activities closely with student training. Six PhD students successfully defended their theses and graduated with their doctor degrees during the project period.
